data-cy="markdown"><h1>Create an Input</h1><div><h2 id="introduction" style="position:relative;"><a href="#introduction" aria-label="introduction permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px"                         </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Introduction</h2>
<p>The purpose of this guide is to walk you through the basic steps of setting up mParticle in your app, unlocking core functionality, and troubleshooting common issues. Along the way, you’ll cover some important concepts you need to understand to be successful with mParticle.</p>
<p>This is not a complete guide to all of mParticle’s features and capabilities. If you already know your way around mParticle and you’re looking for in-depth docs, head to our <a href="/developers">Developers</a> or <a href="/guides">Guides</a> sections.</p>
<aside>
Most of this guide is aimed at users of the mParticle Dashboard, but to follow along with the tutorials, you will need to set up the mParticle SDK in your iOS, Android or web app, so you may need support from a developer to complete some steps.
</aside>
<h3 id="examples" style="position:relative;"><a href="#examples" aria-label="examples permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">
                        <g id="link">
                            <path d="M9.5,12.4 C9.6,12.4 9.7,12.4 9.9,12.4 C9.8,12.5 9.8,12.5 9.7,12.6 L7.5,14.8 C5.8,16.5 3,16.5 1.3,14.8 C-0.4,13.1 -0.4,10.3 1.3,8.6 L3.5,6.4 C3.6,6.3 3.6,6.3 3.7,6.2 C5,5 6.9,4.8 8.4,5.5 C8.8,5.7 9.3,6 9.6,6.4 C10,6.7 10.2,7.2 10.5,7.6 C10.2,7.9 9.9,8 9.5,8 C9.4,8 9.2,8 9.1,7.9 C8.9,7.5 8.5,7.2 8.1,6.9 C7,6.2 5.5,6.4 4.5,7.3 L3.8,8 L2.3,9.5 C1.2,10.6 1.2,12.5 2.3,13.6 C3.4,14.7 5.3,14.7 6.4,13.6 L7.9,12.1 C8.4,12.3 8.9,12.4 9.5,12.4 Z M14.7,1.3 C13,-0.4 10.2,-0.4 8.5,1.3 L6.3,3.5 C6.2,3.6 6.2,3.6 6.1,3.7 C6.7,3.7 7.4,3.7 8,3.9 L9.5,2.4 C10.6,1.3 12.5,1.3 13.6,2.4 C14.7,3.5 14.7,5.4 13.6,6.5 L12.1,8 L11.4,8.7 C10.4,9.7 8.9,9.8 7.8,9.1 C7.4,8.9 7.1,8.5 6.8,8.1 C6.7,8.1 6.5,8 6.4,8 C6,8 5.6,8.2 5.4,8.4 C5.6,8.8 5.9,9.3 6.3,9.6 C6.6,10 7.1,10.2 7.5,10.5 C9,11.2 10.9,11 12.3,9.8 C12.4,9.7 12.4,9.7 12.5,9.6 L14.7,7.4 C16.4,5.7 16.4,3 14.7,1.3 Z" id="Shape"></path>
                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Examples</h3>
<p>The tutorials in this guide follow the process of setting up mParticle in the mPTravel app: a mobile and web app that sells luxury travel packages to its users. </p>
<p>Later on in this guide, you’ll learn about sending data from mParticle to some of our many integration partners. As examples, the tutorials use services which are simple to set up and verify, and which offer a free account tier, so that you will be able follow the examples exactly if you wish. However, mParticle is agnostic about which integrations you choose and you can follow the same basic steps from this guide to implement any of our integrations.</p>
<h2 id="inputs-and-outputs" style="position:relative;"><a href="#inputs-and-outputs" aria-label="inputs and outputs permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">
                        <g id="link">
                            <path d="M9.5,12.4 C9.6,12.4 9.7,12.4 9.9,12.4 C9.8,12.5 9.8,12.5 9.7,12.6 L7.5,14.8 C5.8,16.5 3,16.5 1.3,14.8 C-0.4,13.1 -0.4,10.3 1.3,8.6 L3.5,6.4 C3.6,6.3 3.6,6.3 3.7,6.2 C5,5 6.9,4.8 8.4,5.5 C8.8,5.7 9.3,6 9.6,6.4 C10,6.7 10.2,7.2 10.5,7.6 C10.2,7.9 9.9,8 9.5,8 C9.4,8 9.2,8 9.1,7.9 C8.9,7.5 8.5,7.2 8.1,6.9 C7,6.2 5.5,6.4 4.5,7.3 L3.8,8 L2.3,9.5 C1.2,10.6 1.2,12.5 2.3,13.6 C3.4,14.7 5.3,14.7 6.4,13.6 L7.9,12.1 C8.4,12.3 8.9,12.4 9.5,12.4 Z M14.7,1.3 C13,-0.4 10.2,-0.4 8.5,1.3 L6.3,3.5 C6.2,3.6 6.2,3.6 6.1,3.7 C6.7,3.7 7.4,3.7 8,3.9 L9.5,2.4 C10.6,1.3 12.5,1.3 13.6,2.4 C14.7,3.5 14.7,5.4 13.6,6.5 L12.1,8 L11.4,8.7 C10.4,9.7 8.9,9.8 7.8,9.1 C7.4,8.9 7.1,8.5 6.8,8.1 C6.7,8.1 6.5,8 6.4,8 C6,8 5.6,8.2 5.4,8.4 C5.6,8.8 5.9,9.3 6.3,9.6 C6.6,10 7.1,10.2 7.5,10.5 C9,11.2 10.9,11 12.3,9.8 C12.4,9.7 12.4,9.7 12.5,9.6 L14.7,7.4 C16.4,5.7 16.4,3 14.7,1.3 Z" id="Shape"></path>
                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Inputs and Outputs</h2>
<p>One of the key functions of mParticle is to receive your data from wherever it originates, and send it wherever it needs to go. The sources of your data are inputs and the service or app where it is forwarded are outputs. A connection is a combination of an input and output.</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Inputs include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Apps or services built on any platform we support, such as iOS, Android, or Web. You can view the full list in <strong>SETUP > Inputs</strong> in the PLATFORMS tab.</li>
<li>Data feeds of any other data you want to send into mParticle. This could be data you have collected yourself or from a feed partner. Once configured, feed inputs are listed in <strong>SETUP > Inputs</strong> on the FEEDS tab.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Outputs may be configured for events, audiences, cookie syncs, or data subject requests depending on what the output supports. You can see the list of configured outputs in <strong>SETUP > Outputs</strong> or <strong>SETUP > Data Warehouses</strong>. Outputs include: </li>
<li>Analytics partners such as Indicative  </li>
<li>Advertising partners such as Facebook  </li>
<li>In-app messaging partners such as Braze  </li>
<li>Data Warehouse partners, such as Amazon Redshift, Google BigQuery, or Snowflake </li>
</ul>
<p>To get started with mParticle, you need some data, which means you need to create at least one input.</p>
<h2 id="create-access-credentials" style="position:relative;"><a href="#create-access-credentials" aria-label="create access credentials permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">
                        <g id="link">
                            <path d="M9.5,12.4 C9.6,12.4 9.7,12.4 9.9,12.4 C9.8,12.5 9.8,12.5 9.7,12.6 L7.5,14.8 C5.8,16.5 3,16.5 1.3,14.8 C-0.4,13.1 -0.4,10.3 1.3,8.6 L3.5,6.4 C3.6,6.3 3.6,6.3 3.7,6.2 C5,5 6.9,4.8 8.4,5.5 C8.8,5.7 9.3,6 9.6,6.4 C10,6.7 10.2,7.2 10.5,7.6 C10.2,7.9 9.9,8 9.5,8 C9.4,8 9.2,8 9.1,7.9 C8.9,7.5 8.5,7.2 8.1,6.9 C7,6.2 5.5,6.4 4.5,7.3 L3.8,8 L2.3,9.5 C1.2,10.6 1.2,12.5 2.3,13.6 C3.4,14.7 5.3,14.7 6.4,13.6 L7.9,12.1 C8.4,12.3 8.9,12.4 9.5,12.4 Z M14.7,1.3 C13,-0.4 10.2,-0.4 8.5,1.3 L6.3,3.5 C6.2,3.6 6.2,3.6 6.1,3.7 C6.7,3.7 7.4,3.7 8,3.9 L9.5,2.4 C10.6,1.3 12.5,1.3 13.6,2.4 C14.7,3.5 14.7,5.4 13.6,6.5 L12.1,8 L11.4,8.7 C10.4,9.7 8.9,9.8 7.8,9.1 C7.4,8.9 7.1,8.5 6.8,8.1 C6.7,8.1 6.5,8 6.4,8 C6,8 5.6,8.2 5.4,8.4 C5.6,8.8 5.9,9.3 6.3,9.6 C6.6,10 7.1,10.2 7.5,10.5 C9,11.2 10.9,11 12.3,9.8 C12.4,9.7 12.4,9.7 12.5,9.6 L14.7,7.4 C16.4,5.7 16.4,3 14.7,1.3 Z" id="Shape"></path>
                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Create Access Credentials</h2>
<p>The first thing you need to do is to to create a set of access credentials that will allow a client-side SDK or a server-side application to forward data to this workspace. </p>
<ol>
<li>Login to your mParticle account. If you’re just getting started, your first workspace is created for you. The first screen you see is an overview of activity in the workspace. Since you haven’t yet sent any data, there’s nothing to report, so far.
<img src="/images/gs-empty-account.png"></li>
<li>Navigate to <strong>Setup > Inputs</strong> in the left column. Here you can see each platform type accepted by mParticle. Different platforms are associated with different sets of metadata, such as device identifiers, and most outputs only accept data from a limited set of platforms, so it is important to select the right platform. To capture data from your native Android app, choose <strong>Android</strong>. Just click the <strong>+</strong> next to your chosen platform.
<img src="/images/gs-create-input.png"></li>
<li>Click <strong>Issue Keys</strong>.<br>
<img src="/images/gs-issue-keys.png"></li>
<li>Copy and save the generated Key and Secret.
<img src="/images/gs-copy-keys.png"></li>
</ol>
<h2 id="about-access-credentials" style="position:relative;"><a href="#about-access-credentials" aria-label="about access credentials permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">
                        <g id="link">
                            <path d="M9.5,12.4 C9.6,12.4 9.7,12.4 9.9,12.4 C9.8,12.5 9.8,12.5 9.7,12.6 L7.5,14.8 C5.8,16.5 3,16.5 1.3,14.8 C-0.4,13.1 -0.4,10.3 1.3,8.6 L3.5,6.4 C3.6,6.3 3.6,6.3 3.7,6.2 C5,5 6.9,4.8 8.4,5.5 C8.8,5.7 9.3,6 9.6,6.4 C10,6.7 10.2,7.2 10.5,7.6 C10.2,7.9 9.9,8 9.5,8 C9.4,8 9.2,8 9.1,7.9 C8.9,7.5 8.5,7.2 8.1,6.9 C7,6.2 5.5,6.4 4.5,7.3 L3.8,8 L2.3,9.5 C1.2,10.6 1.2,12.5 2.3,13.6 C3.4,14.7 5.3,14.7 6.4,13.6 L7.9,12.1 C8.4,12.3 8.9,12.4 9.5,12.4 Z M14.7,1.3 C13,-0.4 10.2,-0.4 8.5,1.3 L6.3,3.5 C6.2,3.6 6.2,3.6 6.1,3.7 C6.7,3.7 7.4,3.7 8,3.9 L9.5,2.4 C10.6,1.3 12.5,1.3 13.6,2.4 C14.7,3.5 14.7,5.4 13.6,6.5 L12.1,8 L11.4,8.7 C10.4,9.7 8.9,9.8 7.8,9.1 C7.4,8.9 7.1,8.5 6.8,8.1 C6.7,8.1 6.5,8 6.4,8 C6,8 5.6,8.2 5.4,8.4 C5.6,8.8 5.9,9.3 6.3,9.6 C6.6,10 7.1,10.2 7.5,10.5 C9,11.2 10.9,11 12.3,9.8 C12.4,9.7 12.4,9.7 12.5,9.6 L14.7,7.4 C16.4,5.7 16.4,3 14.7,1.3 Z" id="Shape"></path>
                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>About Access Credentials</h2>
<p>mParticle labels the credentials you create for an integration the key and secret, but they are not exactly like an API key and secret, since you embed these credentials in the app. However, this is not the security risk that exposing API credentials would be:</p>
<ul>
<li>The client-side key and secret can’t read data from the system.</li>
<li>You can <a href="data-master/data-planning/#blocking-bad-data">block bad data</a> to stop any traffic that doesn’t match the data you expect as defined in your schema.</li>
</ul>
<p>Most anonymous client-server architectures, including Adobe, Braze, Firebase, Google Analytics, and Segment don’t have per-session or per-instance credentials, nor does mParticle.</p>
<h2 id="install-and-initialize-an-mparticle-sdk" style="position:relative;"><a href="#install-and-initialize-an-mparticle-sdk" aria-label="install and initialize an mparticle sdk permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">

                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Install and Initialize an mParticle SDK</h2>
<p>You need a developer to help you install and initialize an SDK. See the Getting Started guides for the <a href="/developers/quickstart/ios/overview/">iOS</a>, <a href="/developers/quickstart/android/overview/">Android</a> or <a href="/developers/quickstart/web/overview/">Javascript</a> SDKs to get set up before continuing.</p>
<h2 id="verify-look-for-incoming-data-in-the-live-stream" style="position:relative;"><a href="#verify-look-for-incoming-data-in-the-live-stream" aria-label="verify look for incoming data in the live stream permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">

                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Verify: Look for Incoming Data in the Live Stream</h2>
<ol>
<li>Navigate to <strong>Activity > Live Stream</strong> in the left column. The Live Stream lets you inspect all incoming data from your development environments. It’s an easy way to check that you have correctly initialized mParticle in your app. When you first open up the Live Stream, it will be empty, as we haven’t yet started sending data.
<img src="/images/gs-empty-livestream.png"></li>
<li>Start up a development build of your app (get a developer to help you if necessary). The mParticle SDKs automatically collect and forward data about installs and user sessions, so just by opening a development build of your app, you should start to see data in the Live Stream.
<img src="/images/gs-sessions-livestream.png"></li>
</ol>
<h2 id="advanced-platform-configuration-settings" style="position:relative;"><a href="#advanced-platform-configuration-settings" aria-label="advanced platform configuration settings permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">

                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Advanced Platform Configuration Settings</h2>
<p>For the iOS, Android, tvOS, and Web platforms, some advanced configuration settings are available. To change these settings, navigate to <strong>Setup > Inputs</strong> in the left column and select either iOS, Android, tvOS, or Web from the list of platforms. </p>
<p>Expand the <strong>Advanced Settings</strong> by clicking the + icon.</p>
<h3 id="restrict-device-id-by-limit-ad-tracking" style="position:relative;"><a href="#restrict-device-id-by-limit-ad-tracking" aria-label="restrict device id by limit ad tracking permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">
                        <g id="link">
                            <path d="M9.5,12.4 C9.6,12.4 9.7,12.4 9.9,12.4 C9.8,12.5 9.8,12.5 9.7,12.6 L7.5,14.8 C5.8,16.5 3,16.5 1.3,14.8 C-0.4,13.1 -0.4,10.3 1.3,8.6 L3.5,6.4 C3.6,6.3 3.6,6.3 3.7,6.2 C5,5 6.9,4.8 8.4,5.5 C8.8,5.7 9.3,6 9.6,6.4 C10,6.7 10.2,7.2 10.5,7.6 C10.2,7.9 9.9,8 9.5,8 C9.4,8 9.2,8 9.1,7.9 C8.9,7.5 8.5,7.2 8.1,6.9 C7,6.2 5.5,6.4 4.5,7.3 L3.8,8 L2.3,9.5 C1.2,10.6 1.2,12.5 2.3,13.6 C3.4,14.7 5.3,14.7 6.4,13.6 L7.9,12.1 C8.4,12.3 8.9,12.4 9.5,12.4 Z M14.7,1.3 C13,-0.4 10.2,-0.4 8.5,1.3 L6.3,3.5 C6.2,3.6 6.2,3.6 6.1,3.7 C6.7,3.7 7.4,3.7 8,3.9 L9.5,2.4 C10.6,1.3 12.5,1.3 13.6,2.4 C14.7,3.5 14.7,5.4 13.6,6.5 L12.1,8 L11.4,8.7 C10.4,9.7 8.9,9.8 7.8,9.1 C7.4,8.9 7.1,8.5 6.8,8.1 C6.7,8.1 6.5,8 6.4,8 C6,8 5.6,8.2 5.4,8.4 C5.6,8.8 5.9,9.3 6.3,9.6 C6.6,10 7.1,10.2 7.5,10.5 C9,11.2 10.9,11 12.3,9.8 C12.4,9.7 12.4,9.7 12.5,9.6 L14.7,7.4 C16.4,5.7 16.4,3 14.7,1.3 Z" id="Shape"></path>
                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Restrict Device ID by Limit Ad Tracking</h3>
<p>iOS, Android, and tvOS (Apple TV) devices allow users to limit the collection of advertising IDs. Advertising IDs are unique identifiers you may use to associate event and user data with a specific device. For both iOS and Android devices, if a user has not provided explicit consent to share their device’s advertising ID, then the value of that ID is set to an all-zero value.</p>
<p>By checking <strong>Restrict Device ID by Limit Ad Tracking</strong>, mParticle will not collect advertising IDs from users who have enabled the Limit Ad Tracking setting on their device.</p>
<p>Remember, mParticle will collect advertising IDs for both iOS and Android devices, regardless of whether or not a user has enabled the Limit Ad Tracking setting on their device. However, the IDs collected from users who have opted out will be all-zero values.</p>
<p>Following are descriptions of Apple and Google’s policies for device advertising IDs:</p>
<h4 id="ios-advertising-ids" style="position:relative;"><a href="#ios-advertising-ids" aria-label="ios advertising ids permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">
                        <g id="link">
                            <path d="M9.5,12.4 C9.6,12.4 9.7,12.4 9.9,12.4 C9.8,12.5 9.8,12.5 9.7,12.6 L7.5,14.8 C5.8,16.5 3,16.5 1.3,14.8 C-0.4,13.1 -0.4,10.3 1.3,8.6 L3.5,6.4 C3.6,6.3 3.6,6.3 3.7,6.2 C5,5 6.9,4.8 8.4,5.5 C8.8,5.7 9.3,6 9.6,6.4 C10,6.7 10.2,7.2 10.5,7.6 C10.2,7.9 9.9,8 9.5,8 C9.4,8 9.2,8 9.1,7.9 C8.9,7.5 8.5,7.2 8.1,6.9 C7,6.2 5.5,6.4 4.5,7.3 L3.8,8 L2.3,9.5 C1.2,10.6 1.2,12.5 2.3,13.6 C3.4,14.7 5.3,14.7 6.4,13.6 L7.9,12.1 C8.4,12.3 8.9,12.4 9.5,12.4 Z M14.7,1.3 C13,-0.4 10.2,-0.4 8.5,1.3 L6.3,3.5 C6.2,3.6 6.2,3.6 6.1,3.7 C6.7,3.7 7.4,3.7 8,3.9 L9.5,2.4 C10.6,1.3 12.5,1.3 13.6,2.4 C14.7,3.5 14.7,5.4 13.6,6.5 L12.1,8 L11.4,8.7 C10.4,9.7 8.9,9.8 7.8,9.1 C7.4,8.9 7.1,8.5 6.8,8.1 C6.7,8.1 6.5,8 6.4,8 C6,8 5.6,8.2 5.4,8.4 C5.6,8.8 5.9,9.3 6.3,9.6 C6.6,10 7.1,10.2 7.5,10.5 C9,11.2 10.9,11 12.3,9.8 C12.4,9.7 12.4,9.7 12.5,9.6 L14.7,7.4 C16.4,5.7 16.4,3 14.7,1.3 Z" id="Shape"></path>
                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>iOS Advertising IDs</h4>
<p>After the release of iOS 14.5, Apple introduced the App Tracking Transparency (ATT) framework, which requires app developers to request users’ explicit consent to share their advertising IDs. If a user of your app has not provided this consent, Apple’s advertising ID (IDFA) will be set to all an all-zero value: <code class="language-text">00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000</code>. Read more about Apple advertising identifiers <a href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/adsupport/asidentifiermanager/1614151-advertisingidentifier">in their documentation</a>.</p>
<p>For more information about the ATT framework, visit the <a href="https://docs.mparticle.com/developers/client-sdks/ios/ios14/">iOS 14 Guide</a>.</p>
<h4 id="android-advertising-ids" style="position:relative;"><a href="#android-advertising-ids" aria-label="android advertising ids permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">

            </svg></a>Android Advertising IDs</h4>
<p>Google allows Android users to opt out from sharing their devices’ advertising IDs. Similar to Apple’s policy, Google will set a user’s advertising ID (GAID or AAID) to an all-zero value if that user has opted out from sharing their ID. Read more about Google’s advertising identifiers in <a href="https://support.google.com/googleplay/android-developer/answer/6048248?hl=en">their documentation</a>.</p>

                </g>
            </svg></a>Collect Integration-Specific Identifiers</h3>
<p>The Web SDK can collect integration-specific identifiers to enrich the user data forwarded to your connected outputs.</p>
<p>When <strong>Collect Integration-Specific Identifiers</strong> is checked, these integration-specific identifiers are collected and used to enrich your user data to help optimize the match rate of your audiences in downstream tools. Currently, these identifiers include Facebook’s <a href="https://developers.facebook.com/docs/marketing-api/conversions-api/parameters/fbp-and-fbc"><code class="language-text">fbc</code> and <code class="language-text">fbp</code></a> fields.</p>

<p>If you don’t see data appearing in the Live Stream within the first few minutes after opening a development build:</p>
<ul>
<li>Check that you have copied your Key and Secret correctly</li>
<li>Check that you have properly included the mParticle SDK in your project and it is correctly initialized. The necessary steps will differ depending on the platform. Check our <a href="/developers/quickstart/ios/overview/">iOS</a>, <a href="/developers/quickstart/android/overview/">Android</a> and <a href="/developers/quickstart/web/overview/">Web</a> docs for more.</li>
</ul>

data-cy="markdown"><h1>mParticle Users and Roles</h1><div><h2 id="managing-users" style="position:relative;"><a href="#managing-users" aria-label="managing users permalink" class="anchor before"><svg                         </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Managing Users</h2>
<p>Admin Users can manage the access of other users in their mParticle Account from the <strong>User Management</strong> tab of their User Settings page:</p>
<p><img src="/images/Platform-Update-Mange-Users-042019.png"></p>
<p>To add a new user, provide first and last name, an email address, and select the user’s permissions. See <a href="#roles">Roles</a> for more on permisisons.</p>
<p><img src="/images/Platform-Update-Mange-Users-New-User-042019.png"></p>
<h2 id="roles" style="position:relative;"><a href="#roles" aria-label="roles permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">
                        <g id="link">

                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Roles</h2>
<p>mParticle offers several User Roles with different levels of access to the mParticle Dashboard. You can check your Role from your User Settings page:</p>
<p><img src="/images/Platform-Update-Mange-Users-User-Settings-042019.png" alt="medium"></p>
<p>mParticle’s User Roles are:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>User</strong> - Can view and make updates to all parts of the mParticle platform, excluding the User Activity View, managing other users, and modifying outbound data warehouse configurations.</li>
<li><strong>Read Only</strong> - Has the same view access as ‘User’ level but cannot make any changes or additions.</li>
<li><strong>Admin</strong> - Same access as ‘User’ level, plus the ability to add, remove and manage users and access the User Activity view. This role has access to end-user personal data within the account.</li>
<li><strong>Audiences Only</strong> - Can view and manage Audiences. Cannot view other areas of the mParticle platform. Note that this means Audiences Only users can connect audiences to existing Outputs, but cannot add and configure new Audience Outputs</li>
<li><strong>Compliance</strong> - Can view the Privacy tab, and view and manage <a href="/guides/data-subject-requests/forwarding/#managing-data-subject-requests-in-the-mparticle-dashboard">GDPR requests</a>. Has Read Only access in other parts of the dashboard.</li>
<li><strong>Admin & Compliance</strong> - All Admin permissions, plus can view and manage the Privacy tab, and view and manage <a href="/guides/data-subject-requests/forwarding/#managing-data-subject-requests-in-the-mparticle-dashboard">GDPR requests</a>. This role has access to end-user personal data within the account.</li>
<li><strong>Support Access</strong> - All Admin permissions except for user management capabilities.  Can view the Privacy tab and view <a href="/guides/data-subject-requests/forwarding/#managing-data-subject-requests-in-the-mparticle-dashboard">GDPR requests</a>. This role should be used to delegate access to an mParticle support representative while troubleshooting a ticket. This role has access to end-user personal data within the account.</li>
</ul>

                        </g>
                    </g>
                </g>
            </svg></a>Custom Access Roles API</h3>
<p>mParticle provides the <a href="/developers/apis/custom-roles/">Custom Access Roles API</a> which mParticle account admins can use to create custom sets of permissions, or roles. You can then assign these custom roles to users of your account through the UI described above or with an API call. Learn more in the <a href="/developers/apis/custom-roles/">Custom Access Roles API</a> developer documentation.</p>
<h2 id="authenticating-to-mparticle-with-sso-and-saml" style="position:relative;"><a href="#authenticating-to-mparticle-with-sso-and-saml" aria-label="authenticating to mparticle with sso and saml permalink" class="anchor before"><svg width="16px" height="17px" viewBox="0 0 16 17" version="1.1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
                <g id="Symbols" stroke="none" stroke-width="1" fill="none" fill-rule="evenodd">
                    <g id="Icon/Link" fill="#98A0A3" fill-rule="nonzero">

                </g>
            </svg></a>Authenticating to mParticle with SSO and SAML</h2>
<p>mParticle uses Auth0 to authenticate logins to mParticle’s web UI. This allows you to create a SAML/SSO connection to an identity provider of your choice, such as Okta. Using SAML/SSO, or federated identity management and single sign-on authentication, improves your account’s overall security and the security of your customers’ data.</p>
<p>To enable a SAML/SSO connection, you must collaborate with mParticle’s support team:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Contact mParticle support or your account representitive, and request an ACS (Assertion Consumer Service URL) and an EntityID.</p>
<ul>
<li>Provide mParticle with an SSO URL, an optional logout URL, identity provider domain(s), and signing certificate.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>mParticle will configure an SSO tenant using the details you provided in step 1.</li>
<li>Use the SSO tenant provided by mParticle to implement your existing authentication system and policies.</li>
</ol></div><div class="helpful"><div class="left"><p>Was this page helpful?</p></div><div class="right"><button data-cy="yes-btn" type="button">Yes</button><button data-cy="no-btn" type="button">No</button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="markdown__rightNav"><ul class="headings-toc"><small><i>Last Updated: <!-- -->February 27, 2025</i></small></ul></div></div><footer id="docs-footer" class="footer"><div class="footer-legal"><div class="responsive-container"><nav class="footer-legal__nav"><small class="footer-legal__text" data-cy="footer-legal__text">© 2025 mParticle, Inc.
